args: How do you do? I am Gilbert, the chef\nwho will be representing Seven Leaves.
I thank you for having me here today.\nI cannot tell you how proud I am to be\ntaking over such a splendid establishment.
Gracious, forgive me! I'm getting a bit\nahead of myself, aren't I? Ha ha ha!
Keep your head on, Picaro.\nSettle it at the stovetop.
We've spent three whole days preparing\nthese new recipes—now it's time to wield\nthem as weapons of culinary might!
I will now explain the rules for this\ncooking contest.
Our theme will be ＂creative cuisine.＂\nIn the interest of fairness, we've selected\njudges from a pool of local citizens.
The rules are simple: whosoever impresses\nthe most judges with their dishes wins!
Chefs, to your stations!\nLet the culinary battle...BEGIN!
Do it just like we practiced, you two.\nLet's get this food made.
Heck yeah. I'll prep the vegetables. Picaro,\nyou're on spice duty. You good with that?
But of course! I must participate to\nlegitimize my reclamation of L'Amandier!
(Picaro aside, there certainly seems to\nbe a fire inside those other two chefs.)
(Ah, but creative cuisine is the forte of\nChef Nazuna, and I, her dedicated pupil,\nsimply cannot lose!)
Et voilà! Now to plate and serve!
Ta for now, everyone. The judges are\nabout to embark on a culinary journey,\nwith me as their humble guide.
Speed IS one of the pillars upon which\nSeven Leaves bases its reputation.\nPicaro, how are things on your end?
These are the spices you're using, right?\n...*hurk* Sweet Amaterasu, are you\nTRYING to murder our taste buds, Picaro?!
What do you mean? I'm sure I added the\nproper amount of salt, so— *gag*\nSWEET! TOO SWEET!

Literally ALL you had to do was mix up the
spice blend! How did you manage to hit
the complete opposite end of the flavor
spectrum?!

Because a recipe is useless in my hands!
It matters not how closely I follow
directions—my food always ends up
tasting foul!
Are you kidding me right now? We\npracticed for three days straight, and THIS\nis what it comes to? Well, now what?
Hrm... There's no time to remake it.\nWe need to leverage this flavor as-is.
R-right! Think! Think of a way to make\nsomething delicious using my too-sweet\nmeat! Now go forth, my disciples! COOK!
*sigh* You're something else, man. But\nyeah, if we need to use sweet meat, then...
Your dinner is served, dear guests.\nThis is a Seven Leaves specialty:
Oooh, roast beef? Doesn't look all that\ncreative at first blink, but let's give 'er a\ntaste.
It's delicious! What IS this? A pleasant\ncrunch, mixed with a slightly bittersweet\nflavor, yet so refreshing on the palate!
It is grated daikon radish, flavored with\nwatercress and a balsamic vinegar.
Ah, but that is not all. The meat was\nmarinated in a kombu dashi broth for\na rich, distinctly Hinomotoan flavor.
Mm. A fusion of Hinomotoan and Alberian\nflavors... Just the sort of creative triumph\nI'd expect from Seven Leaves!
You honor me. It's almost a shame that\nthe winner of this contest is already clear\nwhen poor Picaro is still cooking.
As if I would allow such a thing!
Feast your eyes and mouths upon THIS!
Heh heh! Yup. A Hinomoto classic.\nBehold, Salty-Sweet Braised Pork Belly—\nknown in the common parlance as kakuni!
Oho, but did your menu not originally\ncall for your meat to be sautéed?
Could it be that in an attempt to gloss over\na blunder, you hastily reworked your dish?
That's for us to know and you to...not.\nAs for whether we're trying to ＂gloss over＂\nsomething, we'll let the judges decide.
Hmm. So this is based upon a\nHinomotoan dish? Let's just have a bite...

(Heh. Pointless. A long simmer over
low heat is essential for kakuni. Their
last-minute change of plans means that
the flavor won't have penetrated the meat.)
This is truly, marvelously delicious!\nThe pork simply melts in the mouth!
Mm! I'm getting notes of tomato,\ncelery...and is that onion? Such\ncomforting, familiar Alberian flavors!
Familiar...yet new! I can't get enough of\nthis! I like this more than the last dish!
Me too! Please, chef, another serving!
Of all the idiotic—how did they manage\nto season and braise a perfect pork kakuni\nin such a short time?!

We employed a basic technique for
cooking meat in Alberia, which is to slice
meat finely, and through the muscle,
which reduces its toughness.

Then we used a technique from
Hinomoto—starting the meat in cold
water and heating it slowly—to keep
it oh-so-tender.
And the pièce de résistance was my\ncustom L'Amandier cooking pot!
Verily! It is a custom-made device, handed\ndown from one generation of L'Amandier\nchefs to the next!
It is a special sealing pot that applies\nboth heat AND high pressure to the food,\ndrastically reducing cooking time!
A rokkan smith was paid a tidy sum to\ncreate this marvel of kitchen engineering.\nWe call it...a PRESSURE COOKER!
We combined the cooking techniques\nof Alberia and Hinomoto, along with\nL'Amandier's unique cookware...
...making it possible for us to\ntenderize the meat in a flash.
N-no! A chef of Seven Leaves losing a\nbattle of creative cuisine...?! It cannot be!
The judges have decided. We have lost.
I just got here. I knew the match was\nalmost over, so I assumed I'd be coming\nby to take over my new restaurant.
Well, whatever. A loss is a loss.\nAs I promised, I'll back off...for now.
But are you sure there isn't something\nmore important you should be doing\nwith your time, Mitsuba?
Heh heh heh... You'll know before long.\nCome, Gilbert. We're leaving.

WHAT A RELIEF! Thank you, beloved rivals!
I shall be happy to repay the favor by
hiring you on as line cooks at L'Amandier!
Or dishwashers—whatever you prefer!
How magnanimous of you.\nI'm good, though.
(I'm glad we were able to save\nL'Amandier, but what in the world\nwas Nazuna talking about...?)
